required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on November 19, 2021
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Different Modalities in Reducing Airborne Particulate Concentrations During AGP for Health Volunteers
clinical_study.official_title: Comparison of Different Modalities in Reducing Airborne Particulate Concentrations During Aerosol Generating Procedures for Health Volunteers: a Randomized Cross-over Trial

brief_summary.textblock: Several clinical procedures have been described as aerosol generating procedure (AGP), including nebulization, high-flow nasal cannula oxygen therapy, noninvasive ventilation, and bronchial hygiene treatment, etc. However, the understanding on the transmission risk of these treatments is still unclear, particularly the methods to reduce the airborne particulate concentrations during these treatments are still lacking. This study is aimed to compare different modalities in reducing airborne particulate concentrations during these aerosol generating procedures, in order to find the most effective method to reduce particle concentrations, ultimately to decrease the transmission risk and protect health care providers.

primary_outcome.measure: aerosol particle concentrations at 1 foot away from subject's face
primary_outcome.description: aerosol particle concentrations will be recorded continuously for 5 mins during the use of each device at 1 foot away from subject's face

primary_outcome.measure: aerosol particle concentrations at 3 feet away from subject's face
primary_outcome.description: aerosol particle concentrations will be recorded continuously for 5 mins during the use of each device at 3 feet away from subject's face

secondary_outcome.description: subject's comfort will be self-evaluated using a visual numerical scale (VNS) ranging between 1 (very uncomfortable) and 5 (very comfortable)

arm_group.description: Subject will use a standard nebulizer

arm_group.arm_group_label: Nebulization with a filter or scavenger
arm_group.description: Subject will use a nebulizer with a filter placed at the other end of nebulizer mouthpice or a scavenger outside the nebulizer mask
Subject will use high-flow nasal cannula at 40 L/min

arm_group.arm_group_label: High-flow nasal cannula with a scavenger face tent
arm_group.description: Subject will use high-flow nasal cannula at 40 L/min, with a scavenger face tent

arm_group.arm_group_label: High-flow nasal cannula with a surgical mask
arm_group.description: Subject will use high-flow nasal cannula at 40 L/min, with a surgical mask over nasal cannula

intervention.description: Filter is used to capture any individual bacteria or viruses that might be suspended within inhaled or exhaled gases
intervention.arm_group_label: High-flow nasal cannula with a surgical mask
Nebulization with a filter or scavenger

intervention.description: A face tent is connected to a vacuum resource to continuously suction the exhaled gas from the subject, in order to reduce the transmission risk of virus or bacteria
intervention.arm_group_label: High-flow nasal cannula with a scavenger face tent
Nebulization with a filter or scavenger

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
• Ages 18-65, Male or Female
Exclusion Criteria:
- Chronic lung disease, including asthma, COPD, etc.
- Upper airway anatomical abnormities
- Pregnancy
- Uncontrolled Diabetes, hypertension, or untreated thyroid disease
- Has any of the following symptoms in the last 21 days: sore throat, cough, chills, body aches for unknown reasons, shortness of breath for unknown reasons, loss of smell, loss of taste, fever at or greater than 100 degrees Fahrenheit.
- COVID-19 test positive within 21 days.

results_reference.citation: Dhand R, Li J. Coughs and Sneezes: Their Role in Transmission of Respiratory Viral Infections, Including SARS-CoV-2. Am J Respir Crit Care Med. 2020 Sep 1;202(5):651-659. doi: 10.1164/rccm.202004-1263PP. Review.

Li J, Fink JB, Ehrmann S. High-flow nasal cannula for COVID-19 patients: low risk of bio-aerosol dispersion. Eur Respir J. 2020 May 14;55(5). pii: 2000892. doi: 10.1183/13993003.00892-2020. Print 2020 May.

Fink JB, Ehrmann S, Li J, Dailey P, McKiernan P, Darquenne C, Martin AR, Rothen-Rutishauser B, Kuehl PJ, Häussermann S, MacLoughlin R, Smaldone GC, Muellinger B, Corcoran TE, Dhand R. Reducing Aerosol-Related Risk of Transmission in the Era of COVID-19: An Interim Guidance Endorsed by the International Society of Aerosols in Medicine. J Aerosol Med Pulm Drug Deliv. 2020 Dec;33(6):300-304. doi: 10.1089/jamp.2020.1615. Epub 2020 Aug 12. Review.

Kaur R, Weiss TT, Perez A, Fink JB, Chen R, Luo F, Liang Z, Mirza S, Li J. Practical strategies to reduce nosocomial transmission to healthcare professionals providing respiratory care to patients with COVID-19. Crit Care. 2020 Sep 23;24(1):571. doi: 10.1186/s13054-020-03231-8. Review.

patient_data.ipd_description: individual participant data would not be shared
